newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia stands firm on U.N. nuclear treaty move.
newsitem.headline: Australia stands firm on U.N. nuclear treaty move.

text.p: Australia on Wednesday stood firm on plans to push for United Nations approval of a Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty (CTBT), but said its differences with India over the issue would not undermine bilateral relations.

"We and India have different positions on the CTBT. I think what Australia is doing is absolutely right," Foreign Minister Alexander Downer told reporters after launching an Australian trade promotion campaign aimed at India.
"We want to see a successful CTBT concluded and we are doing everything we can to do that in taking the (treaty) resolution to the United Nations General Assembly," Downer said.
"The CTBT is not an issue that I will allow to undermine the strengthening of our bilateral relationship," he said.
The treaty is designed to ban all nuclear explosions used to test or refine atomic weapons.
New Delhi, which exploded a nuclear device in 1974 but has denied possessing atomic weapons, said the treaty was flawed.

After nearly three years of negotiations for a CTBT, India in August vetoed the draft treaty because it allows the five declared nuclear powers to refine their nuclear arsenals through laboratory tests. It also failed to commit them to a timetable for total disarmament.
India also said it opposed a clause that would require its signature to ratify the pact. New Delhi said the measure impinged on its sovereignty.
The five nuclear states are Britain, the United States, Russia, China and France, with India, Pakistan and Israel known as the three threshold states.
Australia has called a meeting of the U.N. General Assembly for September 9 to have it adopt a draft treaty and open it for signature by individual states.
India has said it would demand a two-thirds vote in the United Nations on the treaty, which it opposes, but would not move to prevent the 185-member body from debating the issue.
Asked by an Indian reporter whether a CTBT would result in "nuclear apartheid" and not disarmament, Downer said he preferred not to use such emotive terms.
The minister said it was best to stop the proliferation of nuclear weapons before seeking disarmament by the five powers.
"The first step is to stop the process of proliferation. We believe a CTBT will make a valuable contribution to that process," Downer said.
"If nuclear weapons proliferate, I think we will move into a new era of a deeply dangerous world," he said.

Diplomats say Australia is well-placed to put the draft text before the U.N. Canberra firmly established its anti-nuclear credentials in its fierce campaign against recent French nuclear tests in the South Pacific in a stauch effort that won it worldwide recognition.
